discourse_list.title: DAI \xe2\x80\x94 what centralized elements / vulnerable spots are left?

content.content: I’m curious if there are any centralized elements left in $DAI even after Maker has fully decentralized. Context: I’m trying to get a better sense how decentralized the overall Ethereum ecosystem has become, given (in my opinion) it was not decentralized at all 3-4 years ago. E.g., we probably all know that fiat-backed stablecoins like USDC/USDT have centrally controlled burn/freeze/mint functions that are frequently triggered, basically whenever a government comes knocking. And to give another example, my understanding is that still today, even the “Tier 1” token-based index funds could be drained by a group of 2-4 multisig signers. So, how would I define a centralized element? I’d say: some characteristic of the system that leads to a small number of anonymous actors (let’s say <40 entities) and/or an even smaller number of known actors (real world identities known) being able to influence the protocol in a way that impacts the community, or single members of the community, in a negative way. This would include freezing funds, burning funds, stealing/seizing funds, etc. Basically, how many people would have to collude to do something bad to someone else’s tokens? Or to use a different scenario, how many people would have to be de-anon’d and threatened/coerced? (This is how I define decentralization … censorship resistance.)
content.GPT-summary: The author is asking a question about the level of centralization in the DAI system, even after Maker has fully decentralized. They define centralized elements as characteristics of the system that allow a small number of actors to influence the protocol in a negative way. The author is seeking to understand the level of decentralization in the Ethereum ecosystem.

content.content: Hey, @qwe . Welcome to the forum! @SES-Core-Unit is mapping the risks and launching initiatives to decentralize and scale Maker. Happy to talk about it.

Very nice, how can I stay up to date? Is there a website, a newsletter, a chat, a specific forum / thread I should follow? I have very high hopes that Maker is one of the (in my opinion unfortunately relatively few) Ethereum-based projects with the right priorities (censorship resistance, resilience, etc.), so would love to follow the progress very closely! Until I understand more, I probably won’t be able to contribute much, but I could see myself help in the mid- to long-term.
